all_paragraphs: Philosophy should become better friends with data science. To be clear, data science should play more nicely with Philosophy too. When analyzing the ethical dilemmas that rise from big data, it’s evident that moral philosophy is crucial for improving data science. That’s a discussion for another day though. Today, it is time to discuss the converse; how data science can improve Philosophy.
Questions that will be addressed in this article:
Okay, maybe not that last one. But A+ to you for paying attention.

In order to discuss the mind in relation to neural nets, I want to make sure everyone is on the same page here. There is no need to be a professional data scientist or a philosopher king to participate. I’m going to explain both neural nets and the mind-body problem at a high level so the concepts don’t obscure potential epiphanies. Buckle up, open your mind, and hold on to your predispositions; I present to you: the mind-body problem.

There are two options. Either our body and our mind are two distinct entities [Dualism], or they are one in the same [Monism]. Philosophers have debated this issue since the foundation of religion. If the mind is separate from the body, it’s possible that there exists an eternal soul capable of outliving a decaying earthly self. If the mind is the body though, our thoughts, beliefs, and memories will die simultaneously with our carbon-being.

In order to turn neural nets from a buzzword into comprehensible vocabulary, consider this pancake metaphor. Let’s say that I am a hypothetical pancake connoisseur. Every Sunday, I whip out the buttermilk and the frying pan in an attempt to create the perfect salivation-inducing, butter-melting, sensory-overloading flapjack. But, after years of practice I still can’t seem to make anything greater than a Bisquick flopjack.
I decide the only logical solution is to outsource my pancake creation abilities; I’m going to train a neural net to do it for me. I’ll need a few things:
Don’t focus too heavily on the hidden stuff just yet, we’ll go over that. Notice the significance of the red lines. Each unit from one layer is connected to each unit in the next layer.

Usually the simplest connection weights are numbers between -1 and 1, but for this example the connection weights were randomly chosen to be 8, 2, and 1. This is the first trial’s input for the feature ‘Minutes on Second Side’.

For example, say the activation function = f. Then f(x) would tell us what number to put in the ‘hidden stuff’ (remember x is the summation of all the incoming weights). Words are confusing so take a look at this visual for clarification:

The way that the layers of a neural net work, this process would continue through all of the hidden layers. This is called forward propagation. Finally, the activation function of the output unit(s) would lead to the neural net spitting out ‘Good Pancake’.

In order to make the visuals more understandable, I placed the ‘Good Pancake’ inside of the output unit. Really, the output unit would look something more like f(5.4). Then, based off of some algorithm (ReLU is common) f(5.4) = ‘Good Pancake’.

Keep in mind that there could be many more output units. Maybe f(5.4), f(1.2), f(3), etc… Then the algorithm would take into account all of these output units and spit out ‘Good Pancake’. For simplicity, we’ll stick with one output unit for now.

So how do we fix this? By a process called back propagation, the neural net is able to modify the connection weights so that it will be more likely to guess the correct answer in the future. Theoretically, as I provide more training data, the neural net should learn from its mistakes until it gets as accurate as possible.
Phew, that was a lot of technical jargon. Now we understand what our mind might be and how neural nets work… but how does my mind work?

Think a little bit closer at the example from above. Based off of many trials, the neural net will eventually be able to pretty accurately determine what factors lead to a ‘Good Pancake’ and what factors create a ‘Bad Pancake’.
Isn’t that how humans learn? What if I decided to not outsource my culinary skills to a neural net? Here’s what would happen:

According to my first trial, I make a pancake with butter on the pan, leave it on the first side for a minute, flip it, and leave it on the other side for 30 seconds. I take a bite. That’s a good pancake. Forward propagation.

In the second trial, I’m feeling a bit adventurous. I don’t add any butter to the pan, leave the pancake on the first side for two minutes, flip it, leave it on the other side for one minute, flatten it with a spatula, and take a bite. It wouldn’t take a rocket scientist to figure out that I’ve taken a bite of a terrible pancake. It’s burnt, flat, and dry.

Now I know that at least one of the things I changed from trial one to trial two caused my pancake to go from good to bad. Maybe in my third trial I’ll do the same thing I did in the first trial, but I’ll only change one of those pancake-making attributes. Backward propagation. I make another good pancake.

Eventually, if I do this enough, in theory I will become a pancake making expert. I’ll have created an informal mental algorithm that understands which variability in heat, cooking time for each side, and spatula flattening leads to good pancakes; and which combination of those leads to bad pancakes. Maybe my friends will start to trust my cooking skills. It seems like my mind is working just like a neural net does. Or rather, my mind is working as a Connectionist Network.

Outside of pancake concoction, there are a few other striking arguments in favor of Connectionism. One of the biggest arguments states that neural nets are good at what we are good at, and bad at what we are bad at. I’m talking facial recognition, mental math, memorization, etc. Neural nets struggle with the same problems that our minds struggle with. They are also really great at identifying a familiar face from a crowd.
At this point, the Connectionist argument looks to be a bit promising. But, if my mind can be deduced down to an algorithm… am I even in charge of my own decisions? Does free will exist?

In order to answer the question about free will, we’ll have to check back in with our good old friend Descartes. For proponents of Dualism, free will exists because our mind (soul) is separate from our brain (body). For proponents of pretty much everything else… our mind is just a behavior, a calculation, or a combination of weighted features.

To a Connectionist, if I believe the sky is blue, my thought can be deduced to an input of features that led me to that belief. My knowledge of the color blue and the sky combined with my visual cortex is sent through my neurotransmitters (similar to the diagrams above) in parallel until I reach f(5.7). Or rather, f(5.7) = my belief that the sky is blue.
There’s two questions that still need to be addressed:

In theory, as neural nets become increasingly efficient and scarily accurate, they become more and more like the human brain. Although Connectionism seems to be the most logically promising mind-body theory, the above questions have only been answered in relation to the Computational Theory of the Mind (CTM). Weak AI surrounds us everyday, but Strong AI has yet to be made.

Remember that CTM is similar to a Turing Machine. It explains how the human mind can be narrowed down to a minute set of 0s and 1s. With CTM, the syntax of the world (like the amount of time a pancake is being cooked on one side) combines with our neurotransmitters to create semantics in the world (my burnt pancake tastes bad). Syntax is observable information, semantics are what that information actually means to us.

In the past, humans have thought that strong AI and emotional understanding in AI would stem from semantical understanding. Right now, robots, chatbots, and AI agents can just process information. There isn’t any indication that a higher level of understanding is emerging.

To explain further, imagine this thought experiment (known as the Chinese Room). In this experiment, there is a person in a room filled with filing cabinets. Theoretically, these cabinets are infinitely filled with english-written instructions on how to respond to questions in Chinese. When the person in the room is given a phrase in Chinese slipped underneath the door, they look up instructions for how to respond to the given question, write down the new Chinese characters, and slip it back underneath the door.

It would seem to a bystander that the person in the room is fluent in Chinese. They are able to see questions in Chinese and provide Chinese responses to them. This person would pass the Turing Test. But, does the person in the room actually understand Chinese? They have learned how to create responses from the syntax of written Chinese characters, but they wouldn’t have any knowledge of the language outside of the room. There aren’t any semantics involved.

The same argument is said for AI. Even though robots will most likely get to a point where they can pass a Turing Test and seem as though they are understanding us, is there really any understanding going on in their bot-brain? If AI is created using an instruction-based solution, it follows that the robot would have as little understanding as the man in the Chinese room. Although an AI agent might tell me it “feels sad”, is that statement just a coded response, or is it really feeling sad? True strong AI seems to be better suited for something like a neural net.

The Eliminativist at this point would argue that semantics simply don’t exist. Humans have been deceived by our own brains just as we see a mirage in the desert on a scorching day. We think that we understand the world at some higher level than syntax, but we don’t. Our minds really are nothing but a set of instructions, or a Connectionist Network.

Wow… so according to CTM and Connectionism, the mind is just some scientifically observable entity. There is no metaphysical, divine dimension that my thoughts live in. Life is meaningless. Philosophy and data science are finally playing together in the sandbox, but I don’t know if I want them to anymore!

Don’t worry. It isn’t quite time to deny the existence of free will and submit to a pessimistic, determinist outlook on life just yet. Yes, neural nets are getting better, but that doesn’t necessarily mean Connectionism is the one-stop-shop for strong AI.

First, neural nets take much longer to learn than humans do. Length in this case doesn’t necessarily mean time, it means trials. While networks usually take hundreds of thousands of samples to effectively learn, humans can learn similar tasks in significantly less trials; and usually with greater accuracy.

Second, neural nets struggle with rationality, systematicity, and structure. Basically, this means that humans are better at logic and structure when it comes to language. Take this sentence as an example:
“If Daniel cuts his hair, John will cry. Daniel cuts his hair.”

As humans, we can logically deduce that John will now cry. Interestingly though, neural nets struggle with this concept. Similarly, if Daniel doesn’t cut his hair, neural nets are inclined to think that John will not cry. Which, as propositional logic has proved, isn’t necessarily true.

That’s up to you. There’s a reason that Philosophers have debated this issue for hundreds of years. Neural nets and weak AI are slowly filling some holes in promising theories. This doesn’t mean they are the only answer.

Dualism and determinism will always be at war with one another. Things that can’t be observed (like: the mind) provide gaps in scientific knowledge (like: ‘what is a thought?’). In history, religion acted as a ‘God of the Gaps’. It filled the holes of scientific knowledge. As science got better, religion was needed to explain less and less. In AI, the scientific gaps have historically been filled with Philosophy. Just as the case has been with religion; it seems that as science gets better, certain Philosophical theories are in trouble.

My advice? Try not to overthink it. Our semantics are what we make of them. Maybe my mind is an asomatous being that can make its own decisions and have its own beliefs. Maybe my mind is nothing but 0s and 1s. Whether my thoughts are real or mirages, I’m going to keep living my life; and that’s the best I can do.
